explanation:
I selected fragments that create or register call paths that could lead to direct or indirect recursion and therefore must be investigated: calls to update_directory, calls that replace/destroy cached responses (update_cached_response -> MHD_destroy_response -> response->crfc), creation of responses with a free-callback (crfc) and storage of that callback in the response object, and the registration of notification/completion callbacks with the daemon. These are the likely places where an indirect call chain could loop back to update_directory or to any of the functions shown.

Other code fragments were not flagged because they do not participate in call chains that could produce recursion: list_directory only iterates directory entries and calls standard library functions (snprintf, stat, realloc, closedir) and does not call update_directory or any callback-registrations; mark_as_html and MHD_add_response_header perform header manipulations and call helper functions but do not invoke update_directory; the file-serving branch in generate_page uses MHD_create_response_from_fd and typical I/O functions and does not invoke update_directory except at the explicit call sites already listed; utility functions and straight-line code that allocate, memcpy, snprintf, stat, open/close, or manipulate simple structures do not introduce recursion. Therefore they do not require investigation for Rule 17.2 based on the provided code.
